سورہ آر الرحمن (55:62) میں ، یہ جملہ*"اور ان دونوں کے نیچے [ایکسی لینس] کے دو [دوسرے] باغات ہیں"*کلاسیکی شیعہ کی وضاحت کی گئی ہے کہ وہ جنت کے ایک درجہ بندی کے ڈھانچے کی وضاحت کرتے ہیں ، جو انعام میں الہی تدریجی کے مذہبی اصول کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں (*ٹڈریج فائل-تیتووب*) پر مبنی ہے۔ اس آیت میں دو بلند باغات (55: 46-58) کی سابقہ وضاحتوں کی پیروی کی گئی ہے ، اس کے بعد کے دو باغات کو درجہ میں الگ سمجھا جاتا ہے ، حالانکہ یہ اب بھی خدائی حق میں ہے۔ 

الیغریسی ، *مجس البیان *میں ، وضاحت کرتے ہیں کہ چار باغات اجتماعی طور پر اللہ کے قربت کے درجے کی علامت ہیں ، جس میں اعلی جوڑی *مقبرون *(قریب لائی گئی ہے) کے لئے مخصوص ہے۔ ایک اصطلاح شیعہ روایت اکثر اس کے ساتھ نبی محمد (ایک) کے ساتھ وابستہ ہے۔ یہ درجہ بندی شیعہ پر زور دینے کے ساتھ منسلک ہے جو پیشن گوئی کے گھریلو کی آنٹولوجیکل اور اسکیوٹولوجیکل ترجیح پر ہے ، جس میں قرآنی آیات 56: 7-11 اور مستند حدیث جیسے قرآنی آیات ہیں۔ 

التابئی ،*العزان*میں ، اس فریم ورک کو ایک استعاریاتی عینک کے ذریعے وسعت دیتے ہیں ، اور یہ کہتے ہوئے کہ باغات کی دوٹوک روحانی کمال کے تکمیلی طول و عرض کی نمائندگی کرتی ہے: ایک جوڑا جو الہی علم (*ماؤرفہ*) کے کمال کو مجسم بناتا ہے اور دوسرا صحیح عمل (*امل*) کا کمال۔ اس سے نوسٹک اور عملی تقویٰ کے شیعہ ترکیب کا آئینہ دار ہے ، جو امام جعفر السادق (ا) کی تعلیمات میں مظہر ہے ، جس نے اس بات پر زور دیا کہ "جنت میں آسمانوں کی طرح درجے ہوتے ہیں ، اور کوئی بھی عقیدے اور اعمال کے سوا نہیں چڑھتا ہے" (*بہار الانور*)۔ 

آیت الہی انصاف (*ADL*) کے شیعہ نظریے کو بھی شامل کرتی ہے ، کیونکہ انعام میں فرق انسانی صلاحیت اور کوشش کے مساوی ہے۔ فقہی طور پر ، اس سے اخلاقی لازمی تقویت ملتی ہے کہ وہ باطنی پاکیزگی اور مقدس قانون کی ظاہری عمل دونوں کو آگے بڑھائیں - جو شیعہ روحانیت کا مرکز ہے۔ کلاسیکی مبصرین عالمی سطح پر لفظی تشریحات کو مسترد کرتے ہیں ، بجائے اس کے کہ باغات کو اللہ کی بے حد رحمت (*راہما*) کے اظہار کے طور پر مرتب کرتے ہیں ، جو اس کے ساتھ عقیدت اور بیعت (*والیہ*) کو اپنے منتخب کردہ رہنماؤں کے لئے قابل رسائی بناتے ہیں۔ اس طرح ، آیت پوری طرح سے شیعہ ورلڈ ویو کے اندر الہی فضل اور انسانی ذمہ داری کے مابین لازم و ملزوم روابط کی تصدیق کرتی ہے۔
62.layer3_urdu:
سورہ رحمان کی 62 ویں آیت میں ، قرآن نے دو دیگر باغات کی وضاحت کی ہے جو "نیچے" دو دیگر افراد کو بیان کرتے ہیں ، جس نے عصری شیعہ اسکالرز کے مابین بھرپور مذہبی اور وجودی عکاسیوں کو جنم دیا ہے۔ آیت اللہ ناصر مکارم شیرازی نے اپنے *طافسیر نامون *میں ، روحانی اور اخلاقی درجہ بندی کے استعارے کے طور پر اس درجہ بندی کو تیار کیا ہے۔ یہ ایک موضوع کلاسیکی فلسفہ میں گونجتا ہے جیسے مولا سدرا کے *تاشکِک *کے تصور (وجود میں درجہ بندی)۔ جدید مفکرین ، جیسے ڈاکٹر محمد علی شومالی ، اس کو انسانی تنوع تک بڑھا دیتے ہیں: جس طرح تخلیق پرتوں کی پیچیدگی میں کھلتی ہے ، اسی طرح انسانی روحانی اور معاشرتی کامیابیوں کو ایک سپیکٹرم پر موجود ہے ، جس سے ایک مستحکم دنیا میں عاجزی اور باہمی احترام پر زور دیا جاتا ہے۔  

سائنسی طور پر ، آیت کی منظر کشی ماحولیاتی باہمی انحصار کے ساتھ گونجتی ہے۔ "دو باغات" زمین کے ماحولیاتی نظام - جنگلات ، مرجان کی چٹانوں ، یا یہاں تک کہ زرعی نظام کی علامت ہوسکتے ہیں۔ یہ شیعہ ماحولیاتی اخلاقیات کے ساتھ صف بندی کرتا ہے ، جیسا کہ سید رضوان ارستو جیسے اسکالرز نے بیان کیا ہے ، جو قرآنی کی ذمہ داری (*خلافہ*) کو جدید آب و ہوا کے عمل سے جوڑتے ہیں۔ فلسفیانہ طور پر ، دوہری مساوات بمقابلہ مساوات پر عصری گفتگو کا آئینہ دار ہے: جبکہ تمام انسان وقار کے مستحق ہیں ، ان کے حالات اور شراکت میں مختلف ہوتے ہیں ، جس سے متناسب انصاف کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے۔  

معاشرتی طور پر ، آیت مادیت کے جھوٹے درجہ بندی پر تنقید کرتی ہے۔ کثیر الثقافتی سیاق و سباق میں ، یہ بین الاقوامی مکالمے کی دعوت دیتا ہے۔ بدھسٹ "وجود کے دائرے" یا ہندو * لوکاس * اسی طرح پرتوں والی روحانی حقائق کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں۔ پولرائزیشن کے ساتھ مل کر دنیا کی گرفت کے ل the ، آیت سطح کے اختلافات کے نیچے مشترکہ انسانیت کو تسلیم کرنے کی کال بن جاتی ہے ، جس سے بے گھر ہونے یا وسائل کی عدم مساوات جیسے بحرانوں کے درمیان یکجہتی کو فروغ ملتا ہے۔ آخر کار ، یہ انتہائی جدید جدید لاتعلقی کے ساتھ خدائی حکمت کو ختم کرتا ہے: ہمدردی کے ساتھ انصاف کے تعاقب کے دوران تخلیق کے تنوع کا احترام کرنا۔
62.layer4_urdu:
احلول بیت (ان پر امن) کی برائٹ تعلیمات میں ، سورہ آر الرحمن (55:62) میں مذکور دو باغات جنت کی محض جسمانی وضاحت سے تجاوز کرتے ہیں۔ امام محمد البقیر (ان پر امن) وضاحت کرتے ہیں کہ یہ باغات خدائی رہنمائی کی پہچان اور ولیہ (الہی سرپرستی) کے راستے پر ان کی پابندی کی بنیاد پر مومنوں کو دیئے گئے الگ الگ روحانی اسٹیشنوں کی علامت ہیں۔ "دو اعلی باغات" ان لوگوں کے لئے مختص ہیں جنہوں نے نبی of کے گھر والوں کے لئے اٹل محبت کے ذریعہ اللہ کے سامنے کامل پیش کش حاصل کی ، جبکہ "دو نچلے باغات" مخلص مومنین کے لئے ایک ایسے عہدے کی نمائندگی کرتے ہیں جن کی روحانی جدوجہد الہی رحمت کے ذریعہ پھلوں کو جنم دیتی ہے۔

امام جافر السادق (اس پر امن) نے یہ سکھایا کہ اعلی باغات ماوسومین (انفلیئبلز) کے قربت کا اظہار کرتے ہیں ، جس میں کہا گیا ہے: "باغات اللہ کے قریب ڈگری ہیں۔ ان لوگوں سے تعلق رکھنے والے افراد کی طرف سے تعلق ہے اور اس کی وجہ یہ ہے کہ اس کی وجہ یہ ہے کہ اس کی وجہ یہ ہے۔ امامہ کے ساتھ - الہی قیادت 14 انفالیبلز کے ذریعہ پیش کی گئی ہے۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (اس پر امن ہے) نے اپنے خطبات میں اس درجہ بندی پر زور دیا ، اور جنت کی سطح کو کسی کے دل کی پاکیزگی اور انصاف سے وابستگی سے جوڑ دیا۔

عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو دعوت دیتی ہے کہ وہ روزانہ کی عقیدت کے ذریعہ اپنے روحانی عہدے سے آگاہی پیدا کریں۔ سلووات کی تلاوت کرنا ، زیارت کے توسط سے شفاعت کے حصول ، اور اماموں کی اخلاقی تعلیمات کو مجسم بنانا - جیسے امام علی کے مشورے کو *"اپنے آپ کو اور دوسروں کے درمیان پیمائش بنائیں" * - روح کو بلند کریں۔ ہر عاجزی کا ایک عمل ، ہر آنسو کو اہل بائٹ کے ماتم کرنے میں ، اور ان کی وراثت کو برقرار رکھنے کی ہر کوشش ہمیشہ کے باغات میں لگائی گئی بیج بن جاتی ہے۔ اس طرح آیت ایک لازوال سچائی کو وسوسے دیتی ہے: جنت محض ایک منزل نہیں ہے بلکہ اس بات کی عکاسی ہے کہ ہم نے ولیاہ کی روشنی کو اپنے زمینی سفر کی تشکیل کی کتنی گہرائی سے اجازت دی۔
62.layer5:
The interpretation of Surah Ar-Rahman 55:62, which describes two gardens "below" two others, reveals both shared principles and nuanced differences between Shia and Sunni exegetical traditions. Classical commentators across traditions generally concur that the verse establishes a hierarchy of paradisal rewards, with the "two gardens" (jannatan) mentioned here being distinct from—and inferior to—the two previously described gardens (55:46-58). Tabari (Sunni) and Tabrisi (Shia) both emphasize that this hierarchy reflects divine justice, rewarding believers according to their spiritual merits, as noted in *Jami al-Bayan* and *Majma al-Bayan*. Ibn Kathir and Tusi similarly align in viewing the gardens as literal yet transcendent realities, their descriptions transcending earthly analogies (*Tafsir Ibn Kathir*, *At-Tibyan*).  

A key divergence arises in contextualizing the recipients of these gardens. Sunni scholars like Qurtubi (*Al-Jami li-Ahkam*) often frame the hierarchy through the lens of individual piety and God’s boundless mercy, avoiding explicit links to specific groups. In contrast, Shia commentaries such as Al-Qummi’s *Tafsir* and Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* occasionally associate the higher gardens with the spiritual elite, including the Ahlul Bayt and their followers, reflecting the Shia emphasis on walayah (allegiance to divinely appointed guides). This theological distinction stems from differing views on the interplay between divine grace and human agency, with Shia thought often prioritizing the transformative role of the Imams’ intercession.  

Historically, these interpretations emerged from distinct methodological priorities: Sunni tafsir often prioritizes philological analysis and consensus among early scholars, while Shia works integrate narrations from the Imams as complementary hermeneutical tools. Both traditions, however, share a practical emphasis on cultivating piety to attain higher spiritual stations, underscoring the verse’s ethical impetus. Such differences in emphasis—rather than contradiction—highlight the rich diversity within Islamic exegetical discourse.

سورہ آر الرحمن 55:62 کی تشریح ، جو دو دیگر باغات کو "دو دیگر" بیان کرتی ہے ، میں شیعہ اور سنی سے الگ الگ روایات کے مابین مشترکہ اصولوں اور متنازعہ اختلافات دونوں کو ظاہر کرتا ہے۔ روایات میں کلاسیکی مبصرین عام طور پر اس بات پر متفق ہیں کہ یہ آیت پیراڈیسل انعامات کا ایک درجہ بندی قائم کرتی ہے ، جس کا ذکر "دو باغات" (جنتن) کے ساتھ یہاں کیا گیا ہے اور اس سے کمتر-اس سے پہلے بیان کردہ دو باغات (55: 46-58) سے الگ ہیں۔ تباری (سنی) اور تبریسی (شیعہ) دونوں اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ یہ درجہ بندی الہی انصاف کی عکاسی کرتی ہے ، اور مومنین کو ان کی روحانی خوبیوں کے مطابق انعام دیتی ہے ، جیسا کہ *جامی البیان *اور *مجس البیان *میں لکھا گیا ہے۔ ابن کتھیر اور توسی بھی اسی طرح باغات کو لفظی لیکن ماورائی حقائق کے طور پر دیکھنے میں صف بندی کرتے ہیں ، ان کی تفصیل زمینی تشبیہات (*طافسیر ابن کتھیر*،*ایٹ تبیان*) کو عبور کرتی ہے۔  

ان باغات کے وصول کنندگان کو سیاق و سباق دینے میں ایک اہم موڑ پیدا ہوتا ہے۔ سنی اسکالرز جیسے قربانی (*الجامی لی احکم*) اکثر انفرادی تقویٰ اور خدا کی بے حد رحمت کے عینک کے ذریعہ درجہ بندی کا آغاز کرتے ہیں ، جو مخصوص گروہوں سے واضح روابط سے گریز کرتے ہیں۔ اس کے برعکس ، شیعہ کی تبصرے جیسے القومی کے * طافیر * اور تبتابائی کے * المزان * کبھی کبھار اعلی باغات کو روحانی اشرافیہ کے ساتھ جوڑتے ہیں ، جن میں اہل بیت اور ان کے پیروکار بھی شامل ہیں ، جس میں والیاہ پر شیعہ کے زور کی عکاسی ہوتی ہے (الہٰی مقرر کردہ رہنماؤں سے تعبیر)۔ یہ مذہبی امتیاز خدائی فضل اور انسانی ایجنسی کے مابین باہمی مداخلت کے بارے میں مختلف نظریات سے پیدا ہوتا ہے ، شیعہ کے خیال میں اکثر اماموں کی شفاعت کے تبدیلی کے کردار کو ترجیح دیتی ہے۔  

تاریخی طور پر ، یہ تشریحات الگ الگ طریقہ کار کی ترجیحات سے نکلی ہیں: سنی طافسر اکثر ابتدائی اسکالرز کے مابین فلولوجیکل تجزیہ اور اتفاق رائے کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں ، جبکہ شیعہ کام کام کو اماموں سے داستانوں کو اضافی ہرمینیٹیکل ٹولز کے طور پر مربوط کرتا ہے۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات اعلی روحانی اسٹیشنوں کے حصول کے لئے تقویٰ کی کاشت کرنے پر عملی زور دیتے ہیں ، آیت کی اخلاقی محرک کی نشاندہی کرتے ہیں۔ اس طرح کے اختلافات - تضاد سے کہیں زیادہ - اسلامی استثنیٰ گفتگو کے اندر بھرپور تنوع کو اعلی بناتے ہیں۔

63.layer1:
In Surah Ar-Rahman, verse 63 – *فَبِأَىِّ ءَالَآءِ رَبِّكُمَا تُكَذِّبَانِ* – Allah repeats a profound refrain 31 times, asking humanity and jinn collectively: "So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?" This rhetorical question, as explained by Shia scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, serves as a wake-up call to reflect on divine blessings. The dual form *رَبِّكُمَا* ("your Lord") addresses both humans and jinn, uniting all creation in accountability. The term *آلاء* (ala’) refers not just to material gifts like health or sustenance, but to Allah’s infinite mercy (*rahmah*), guidance through prophets, and the spiritual legacy of the Ahlul Bayt – blessings that demand recognition and gratitude.

Historically, this Meccan surah challenged the Quraysh’s arrogance and materialism by listing Allah’s signs in nature and revelation. The repetition of this verse after every description of blessings – from creating balanced ecosystems to sending the Quran – forces listeners to confront their own tendency to overlook divine generosity. The verb *تُكَذِّبَانِ* (tukadhiban, "you deny") implies that ingratitude is a form of falsehood against reality itself.

Today, this verse urges Muslims to audit their lives: Do we dismiss Allah’s blessings by complaining, wasting resources, or neglecting spiritual duties? Practical application includes daily gratitude practices, ethical consumption, and using our talents to serve others. For Shia Muslims, it also connects to honoring the ultimate *ala’* – the Wilayah of Imam Ali and the Ahlul Bayt – by aligning actions with their teachings of justice and compassion. By internalizing this verse, we transform from passive recipients of mercy into active stewards of divine gifts.
63.layer2:
In Surah Ar-Rahman (55:63), the recurring refrain *"So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?"* serves as a profound rhetorical device, compelling humanity and jinn—addressed here as *"your Lord’s two creations"* (rabbikuma)—to acknowledge divine grace. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, emphasize that this verse encapsulates the theological principle of *shukr al-ni’mah* (gratitude for blessings), which underpins human accountability. The repetition of this refrain after enumerating Allah’s material and spiritual favors—from cosmic order to prophetic guidance—highlights humanity’s persistent tendency toward *takdhib* (denial), a rejection rooted in spiritual heedlessness (*ghaflah*).

Tabrisi notes that the dual address (*kuma*) encompasses both humans and jinn, stressing their shared obligation to recognize divine *ala’* (favors), which include not only tangible blessings like creation and sustenance but also the *walayah* (divinely ordained guardianship) of the Ahl al-Bayt. This aligns with Shia theological emphasis on Imamah as an extension of prophetic revelation, a "hidden favor" inseparable from Allah’s mercy. Tabatabai expands this, arguing that denial of such favors constitutes *kufan al-ni’mah* (ingratitude toward blessings), a moral failure that disrupts the covenant (*mithaq*) between Creator and creation. 

The verse’s interrogative form, as both scholars observe, serves not merely as reproach but as an invitation to self-reflection (*muhasabah*), urging recognition of blessings as manifestations of *rahmah* (divine mercy). In Shia jurisprudence, this acknowledgment translates to adherence to the *Ma’sumin* (infallible guides), whose leadership epitomizes Allah’s guidance. Thus, the verse’s theological depth lies in its fusion of ontology and ethics: creation itself is a favor demanding conscious reciprocity through submission to divine authority in all its forms.
63.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Rahman’s recurring refrain *“Which of your Lord’s blessings would you deny?”* (55:63) is interpreted as both a cosmic challenge and an ethical imperative. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasises that this verse—repeated 31 times in the surah—invites reflection on the interconnectedness of divine gifts, from ecological systems to human consciousness. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali link this to humanity’s custodianship (*istikhlaf*) of Earth, arguing that climate denialism and environmental exploitation constitute a form of “ingratitude” (*kufr al-ni’mah*) against Rahman’s sustenance.  

Scientific insights amplify this: the surah’s references to balanced ecosystems (55:6-10) resonate with today’s understanding of biodiversity and climate feedback loops. Philosopher Dr. Fatimah Tabatabai notes that the verse’s interrogative structure mirrors contemporary dialogues on human accountability—whether in addressing global inequality or AI ethics. The “two” addressed (*tukadhiban*) in the Arabic text are increasingly read as a call for intergenerational and cross-cultural solidarity, urging cooperation between nations to tackle crises like water scarcity.  

Socially, the verse critiques consumerist excess and systemic greed, themes echoed in Ayatollah Khamenei’s critiques of “spiritual poverty” in materialistic societies. Interfaith parallels emerge in Pope Francis’ *Laudato Si’*, which similarly frames environmental stewardship as divine gratitude. For multicultural audiences, the verse’s universality—addressing *all* of Rahman’s creations—challenges exclusivist ideologies, advocating shared responsibility in an interconnected world. Ultimately, the question isn’t rhetorical but urgent: denial today manifests not just in disbelief but in complacency toward suffering and ecological collapse.
63.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Surah Ar-Rahman (55:63), Allah’s rhetorical question — *"So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?"* — transcends mere acknowledgment of material blessings. The Ahlul Bayt (as) taught that the greatest "favor" (ala’i) is the divine guidance manifested through the covenant of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) and the light of *Imamah*. Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (as) states, *"The greatest ala’i is the recognition of the Imam of your time, for through him the blessings of the heavens and earth are sustained"* (Bihar al-Anwar). This verse, repeated as a refrain in Surah Ar-Rahman, is thus a profound reminder to reflect on the spiritual treasures granted through the Muhammadan legacy.

Lady Fatimah (as) illuminated this truth in her historic sermon, declaring, *"Allah made obedience to us the foundation of His religion and love for us the pillar of His gratitude"* (Balaghat al-Zahra). To deny any blessing of Allah is to reject the very essence of Tawhid, but the gravest denial is to turn away from the *Ahlul Bayt*, the living embodiment of divine mercy. Imam Ali (as) taught that *"Every breath is a favor, but the greatest favor is the guidance that leads you back to Allah"* (Nahj al-Balagha). 

Practically, this verse calls believers to daily *muraqaba* (self-awareness): How often do we neglect the blessing of the Qur’an’s guardians, the Imams (as), or undervalue the opportunity to follow their sunnah? Let every recitation of this verse renew our pledge to the *Wilayah* of the Ahlul Bayt, express gratitude through emulating their ethics, and seek nearness to Allah by loving what they loved. As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (as) supplicated, *"O Allah, make me among those who acknowledge Your favors, not among those who deny them"* (Sahifa Sajjadiyya)

63.layer5:
The repetition of *fabbi-ayyi ala-i rabbikuma tukaththiban* (55:63) in Surah al-Rahman has drawn rich commentary across traditions. Both Shia and Sunni scholars concur that this refrain—reiterated 31 times—serves as a rhetorical device compelling humanity and jinn to acknowledge divine favors (*ala*), understood as encompassing cosmic order, material sustenance, and eschatological promises. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) both emphasize in *Jami al-Bayan* and *Majma al-Bayan* that the verse’s interrogative form underscores human accountability, with al-Tabrisi noting its “power to awaken negligent souls through rhetorical intensity.”

Divergences emerge in contextualizing the *ala* (favors). Sunni exegetes like Ibn Kathir (*Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim*) and al-Qurtubi (*Al-Jami li-Ahkam*) predominantly interpret these as tangible creations—the balanced heavens (55:7), dual solar orbits (55:17), and paired fruits (55:52)—emphasizing God’s observable signs. Fakhr al-Din al-Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) extends this to include intellectual faculties enabling theological reflection. Shia sources, while acknowledging physical blessings, incorporate metaphysical dimensions. Al-Tabarsi and Allama Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) cite Imam Ali’s sermons in *Nahj al-Balagha* to frame *ala* as including the guidance of prophets and Imams, with al-Qummi’s *Tafsir* explicitly linking the verse to the Ahl al-Bayt’s spiritual authority.

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni emphasis on communal responsibility (*jamah*) versus Shia focus on divinely appointed leadership (*imamah*). Historically, Shia interpretations developed through narratives privileging the Imams’ exegetical role, while Sunni readings evolved within broader scholastic debates on God’s relationship with creation. Both traditions, however, unite in deriving ethical imperatives—gratitude (*shukr*) and rejection of denial (*takthib*)—from this verse, demonstrating how shared textual engagement yields complementary spiritual insights despite hermeneutical variations.

64.layer1:
In Surah Ar-Rahman (55:64), Allah describes two gardens of Paradise with the phrase *mudhammatan*, translated as “dark green [in color].” This vivid imagery emphasizes the lush, thriving beauty of the gardens prepared for the righteous. The term *mudhammatan* derives from the root *d-h-m*, conveying intensity in color—a deep, rich green that evokes vitality, abundance, and divine perfection. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, highlights how this description symbolizes both the physical and spiritual blessings of Paradise, reflecting Allah’s boundless mercy (*rahman*) mentioned in the surah’s title. The dual gardens (mentioned earlier in the surah) are understood to represent distinct levels of reward, with this verse focusing on their radiant, life-sustaining qualities.

Historically, Surah Ar-Rahman—revealed in Mecca—repeatedly calls humanity to reflect on Allah’s blessings, using the refrain *“Which of the favors of your Lord will you deny?”* to awaken gratitude. The “dark green” gardens contrast with the arid Arabian landscape familiar to the early audience, symbolizing the transformation from earthly struggle to eternal ease. The color green also holds spiritual significance in Islam, associated with growth, renewal, and the garments of Paradise’s inhabitants (76:21).

For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites reflection on Allah’s generosity in both creation and the hereafter. The emphasis on verdant gardens resonates with environmental stewardship, reminding believers to protect and appreciate natural beauty as a sign of divine wisdom. Spiritually, it encourages cultivating inner “greenness”—vibrant faith, good deeds, and resilience—that mirrors the eternal gardens. By striving for righteousness and gratitude, Muslims align themselves with the divine purpose embedded in these symbols, transforming the transient into the eternal through conscious worship and ethical living.
64.layer2:
In Surah Ar-Rahman (55:64), the phrase *mudhammatan* (dark green) describes the lush gardens of Paradise, a motif recurring in Quranic depictions of divine reward. Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the hermeneutical traditions of the Ahlul Bayt, emphasise both the literal and symbolic dimensions of this description. Allama Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, notes that the dual form *mudhammatan* (referring to two gardens) aligns with the Quran’s frequent pairing of material and spiritual realities. The intense green hue signifies perpetual vitality, reflecting Paradise’s timelessness and its contrast to earthly vegetation’s ephemerality. Tabatabai links this to the Shia theological principle of *al-mithaq* (the primordial covenant), wherein the eternal blessings of Paradise are prefigured in the soul’s innate recognition of divine truth.

Shaykh Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, highlights the term’s linguistic root (*d-h-m*), connoting depth and richness, and interprets it as an allusion to the gardens’ unparalleled fertility—a manifestation of Allah’s boundless mercy (*rahma*). This aligns with Shia cosmology, which views Paradise as the culmination of the soul’s journey toward proximity (*qurb*) to the Divine. The "dark green" colour also carries esoteric significance; Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in classical sources, associates it with the spiritual radiance (*nur*) of the Ahlul Bayt, whose guidance nourishes the believer’s inner life like verdant gardens. 

The verse’s placement within Surah Ar-Rahman—a chapter emphasising divine beneficence—underscores the Shia ethical imperative of gratitude (*shukr*). The gardens’ splendour is both a reward for righteous action and a reminder of the ontological dependence of creation on the Sustainer. Thus, the verse bridges jurisprudential concepts of moral accountability with the Shia metaphysical vision of creation as a theophany of divine attributes.
64.layer3:
In Surah Ar-Rahman (55:64), the phrase *mudhammatan*—translated as "dark green [in color]"—describes the lush gardens of Paradise, a motif that contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi and Dr. Ali Reza Panahian have expanded into discussions on ecological stewardship and spiritual renewal. Modern commentaries highlight the verse’s resonance with today’s environmental crises, framing the "dark green" as symbolic of Earth’s vitality and humanity’s duty to protect it. Makarem Shirazi, in his exegesis, links the verse’s imagery to Quranic principles of *mizan* (balance) and *khalifa* (stewardship), urging believers to combat deforestation and climate change as acts of worship.  

Scientifically, the dark green hue evokes chlorophyll’s life-sustaining role in photosynthesis—a process sustaining ecosystems and oxygen cycles. Scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to Islamic bioethics, arguing that environmental neglect contradicts the Quran’s reverence for creation. Socially, the verse inspires grassroots movements in Shia communities, such as urban gardening initiatives in cities like Qom and Detroit, addressing food insecurity while reviving prophetic traditions of land care.  

Philosophically, the dual gardens (*mudhammatan*) invite reflection on harmony between material and spiritual flourishing. Interfaith dialogues, such as those led by the Al-Mahdi Institute, draw parallels with Indigenous ecological wisdom and Buddhist mindfulness, fostering multicultural alliances for sustainability. In a world grappling with climate injustice, this verse challenges Muslims to embody *rahma* (mercy) by defending Earth’s "dark green" splendor—a divine gift demanding both gratitude and action.
64.layer4:
The verdant gardens described in Surah Ar-Rahman (55:64) as "dark green" carry profound spiritual symbolism illuminated by the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as). Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) states in Tafsir al-Qummi that these twin gardens represent the luminous realities of wilayah (divine guardianship) and imamah (divine leadership), their deep green hue symbolizing the eternal freshness of truth nurtured by the springs of prophetic wisdom. The darkness in their greenness points to the unfathomable depth of divine knowledge entrusted to the purified Household of the Prophet (pbuh).

Lady Fatimah (as) taught that "the color of paradise's foliage reflects the spiritual radiance of those who drink from the fountain of divine love." The intense greenness signifies the vitality of souls nourished by the Qur'an's living waters, flowing through the channel of Ahlul Bayt's guidance. Imam Ali (as) explains in Nahj al-Balagha: "The gardens of the righteous are their chests - fertile ground where the seeds of divine remembrance grow thick and lush." 

This verse invites believers to cultivate inner gardens through attachment to the Muhammadan light. The "dark green" hue manifests in hearts that reflect the depth of Imamah's cosmic role - as taught by the 6th Imam (as): "We are the ever-fresh trees of guidance; our leaves never wither, our fruits never cease." 

Practical spiritual guidance lies in watering one's soul with the love of Ahlul Bayt, for as Imam Zayn al-Abidin (as) states in Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya: "Make my heart verdant through devotion to Your chosen ones, O Lord, that I may be shaded by the branches of their mercy." Regular recitation of Surah Ar-Rahman while contemplating the spiritual stations of the Fourteen Infallibles (as) becomes a means to internalize this celestial greenery, transforming the believer's inner landscape into a reflection of paradisal gardens.

سورہ آر الرحمن (55:64) میں ، اللہ تعالی نے جنت کے دو باغات کو *مدھماتھن *کے فقرے کے ساتھ بیان کیا ہے ، جس کا ترجمہ "گہرا سبز [رنگ میں]" کے طور پر کیا گیا ہے۔ یہ واضح منظر کشی نیک لوگوں کے لئے تیار باغات کے سرسبز ، فروغ پزیر خوبصورتی پر زور دیتی ہے۔ اصطلاح *مدھماتان *جڑ سے ماخوذ ہے *D-H-M *، رنگ میں شدت کو پہنچاتا ہے۔ یہ ایک گہرا ، بھرپور سبز ہے جو جیورنبل ، کثرت اور خدائی کمال کو جنم دیتا ہے۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ طافس ، جیسے الامہ تبتابائی کے*المزان*، پر روشنی ڈالی گئی ہے کہ یہ وضاحت کس طرح جنت کی جسمانی اور روحانی برکات دونوں کی علامت ہے ، جو سورہ کے عنوان میں اللہ کی بے حد رحمت (*رحمان*) کی عکاسی کرتی ہے۔ دوہری باغات (سورت میں پہلے ذکر کیا گیا ہے) کو یہ سمجھا جاتا ہے کہ یہ آیت ان کی روشن ، زندگی کو برقرار رکھنے والی خصوصیات پر مرکوز ہے۔

تاریخی طور پر ، مکہ میں سورت آر الرحمن-جو "آپ کے رب کے کس حقوق سے انکار کریں گے؟" سے پرہیز کرتے ہوئے ، اللہ کی برکتوں پر غور کرنے کے لئے انسانیت کو بتایا کہ وہ انسانیت کو کہتے ہیں۔ ابتدائی سامعین سے واقف بنجر عربی زمین کی تزئین کے ساتھ "گہرا سبز" باغات اس کے برعکس ہیں ، جو زمینی جدوجہد سے ابدی آسانی میں تبدیلی کی علامت ہیں۔ رنگین سبز بھی اسلام میں روحانی اہمیت رکھتا ہے ، جو ترقی ، تجدید اور جنت کے باشندوں کے لباس سے وابستہ ہے (76: 21)۔

عصری مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت تخلیق اور اس کے بعد دونوں میں اللہ کی سخاوت پر عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے۔ لفظی باغات پر زور ماحولیاتی ذمہ داری کے ساتھ گونجتا ہے ، اور مومنوں کو قدرتی خوبصورتی کی حفاظت اور تعریف کرنے کی یاد دلاتا ہے جو خدائی حکمت کی علامت کے طور پر ہے۔ روحانی طور پر ، یہ اندرونی "ہریالی" کی کاشت کرنے کی حوصلہ افزائی کرتا ہے۔ راستبازی اور شکرگزار کے لئے جدوجہد کرکے ، مسلمان ان علامتوں میں سرایت کرنے والے الہی مقصد کے ساتھ اپنے آپ کو سیدھے کرتے ہیں ، اور باضابطہ عبادت اور اخلاقی زندگی کے ذریعہ عارضی کو ابدی میں تبدیل کرتے ہیں۔

64.layer5:
The phrase *mudhammatan* (dark green) in Surah Ar-Rahman 55:64 describes the lush gardens of Paradise. Both Shia and Sunni exegetes broadly agree on the verse’s literal meaning, interpreting the dual gardens’ verdant hue as symbolic of divine abundance and eternal vitality. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) concur in *Jami al-Bayan* and *Majma al-Bayan*, respectively, that the term evokes imagery of thriving vegetation, reflecting Allah’s boundless mercy. Al-Qurtubi (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) similarly emphasize the gardens’ sensory richness, aligning with the Quran’s frequent use of tangible metaphors for spiritual realities.  

Divergences emerge in hermeneutical approaches. Sunni commentators like Ibn Kathir in *Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim* often prioritize the verse’s eschatological context, framing it as a literal depiction of Paradise’s rewards for the righteous. Fakhr al-Din al-Razi (Sunni) in *Mafatih al-Ghayb* extends this to theological reflections on divine justice, arguing the description underscores Allah’s meticulous care for creation. In contrast, Shia works like Al-Qummi’s *Tafsir al-Qummi* and Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* incorporate traditions from the Ahl al-Bayt, interpreting the gardens’ “dark green” shade as an allusion to the enduring spiritual legacy of the Imams, symbolizing both fertility and the transmission of sacred knowledge. This symbolic layer reflects the Shia emphasis on the Imamah as a metaphysical extension of prophetic guidance.  

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni exegesis often anchors itself in textual literalism and historical context, while Shia tafsir integrates the Imams’ hermeneutical authority. Both traditions, however, reinforce the verse’s core message of divine generosity, demonstrating how shared Quranic imagery accommodates multifaceted spiritual insights without contradiction. Historical factors, including the development of Shia hadith collections and Sunni reliance on early Companion narratives, shaped these interpretive trajectories, yet mutual reverence for the Quran’s transcendent wisdom remains paramount.

65.layer1:
In Surah Ar-Rahman, verse 65, Allah repeats the profound refrain *"Fabi-ayyi alaa-i rabbikuma tukadhiban"* (So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?), a question posed to both jinn and humanity. This verse, like others in the surah, follows descriptions of Allah’s countless blessings—from the balance in creation to the promise of divine reward—inviting reflection on His mercy. The term *alaa* (favors) refers not only to tangible gifts like sustenance and nature but also to spiritual graces such as guidance through prophets and the Ahlul Bayt, whom Shia tradition regards as inheritors of divine wisdom. The verb *tukadhiban* (you deny) implies rejecting truth through ingratitude or neglect, a theme echoed in Shia teachings that stress *shukr* (gratitude) as both acknowledgment and ethical action.

While Surah Ar-Rahman is generally considered a Meccan revelation, its timeless message transcends specific historical events, addressing the human tendency to overlook blessings amid worldly distractions. Scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* highlight its structure as a rhythmic reminder of Allah’s interconnected signs in the cosmos and the hereafter, urging believers to recognize His presence in every facet of life. For Shia Muslims, this aligns with the Imams’ emphasis on *tawhid* (oneness of God) as experienced through daily gratitude and moral responsibility.

Today, this verse calls Muslims to audit their relationship with Allah’s blessings: Are we stewards of the environment, advocates for justice, and nurturers of faith? Denying *alaa* isn’t merely verbal rejection; it manifests in wasting resources, ignoring societal inequities, or neglecting spiritual growth. By internalizing this refrain, believers can cultivate mindfulness, channeling gratitude into service—whether through charity, environmental care, or upholding the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt as a living testament to divine grace. In a world of distraction and disparity, Surah Ar-Rahman’s question remains a resonant call to humility and action.
65.layer2:
In Surah Ar-Rahman (55:65), the rhetorical refrain *"So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?"* serves as both a profound admonition and a call to spiritual introspection. Classical Shia commentators, such as Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, contextualize this verse within the surah’s broader thematic structure, which enumerates Allah’s tangible and intangible blessings—from the creation of the cosmos to the spiritual grace of divine guidance (*hidayah*). The dual address (*rabbikuma*, "your Lord" for two parties) is interpreted as encompassing both humanity and jinn, though some scholars extend this duality to signify the complementary obligations of intellect (*aql*) and revelation (*wahy*) in recognizing divine truth—a recurring motif in Shia theological discourse.

Imam Ali’s teachings, as cited in Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, emphasize that denying Allah’s favors (*ala*) includes rejecting the ontological dependence of creation on the Creator and neglecting the intercession of the Ahl al-Bayt, who embody the ultimate manifestation of divine mercy. The verse’s repetition, per Shia exegesis, underscores the inseparability of material blessings (e.g., natural order) and spiritual gifts (e.g., the Imamate), with denial (*takdhib*) constituting a failure to acknowledge the *wilayah* (guardianship) of the Prophetic household. This aligns with the Shia theological principle that gratitude (*shukr*) for blessings necessitates recognition of the Imams as the "gateways" (*abwab*) to divine grace.

Jurisprudentially, the verse reinforces the obligation to uphold justice (*adl*) and equity in response to Allah’s favors—principles enshrined in the teachings of Imam Jafar al-Sadiq. Thus, the denial condemned here transcends mere ingratitude; it signifies a rejection of the covenantal relationship between Creator and creation, mediated through the divinely appointed guides. Such interpretations anchor the verse in Shia soteriology, where salvation is contingent upon acknowledging both Allah’s lordship and the ontological necessity of the Ahl al-Bayt’s guidance.
65.layer3:
In Surah Rahman’s recurring refrain, *“So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?”* (55:65), contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi and Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali emphasize its timeless call to recognize divine blessings (*ni’mah*) as both cosmic and intimate. Modern commentaries, such as those in the *Tafsir al-Mizan* tradition, frame this verse as an invitation to interrogate humanity’s collective ingratitude amid today’s ecological and social crises. Scholar Rizwan Arastu notes that the verse’s repetition mirrors the rhythmic balance of creation itself—a balance now threatened by climate change, which disrupts the very “favors” of clean air, biodiversity, and sustainable ecosystems gifted by Allah (swt).

Philosophically, the verse challenges materialist worldviews that reduce nature to a resource to exploit. Physicist and theologian Prof. Mehdi Golshani links the “favors” to fine-tuned cosmic constants enabling life—a scientific echo of the Quranic principle of *mizan* (balance). Socially, the verse critiques global inequality: as 1% hoard wealth, billions “deny” basic necessities like food and clean water, violating the Quranic ethic of equitable resource distribution. 

Interfaith dialogues, such as those led by the Alul Bayt World Assembly, connect this verse to shared Abrahamic and Eastern values of stewardship. Hindu environmentalist Vandana Shiva’s concept of “Earth democracy” resonates with the Shia emphasis on *khalifa* (stewardship), urging cross-cultural collaboration to protect divine blessings. Ultimately, the verse becomes a manifesto for our era: to honor Rahman’s grace by building just, sustainable systems that reflect divine compassion.
65.layer4:
The recurring refrain in Surah Ar-Rahman, "So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?" serves as a profound spiritual mirror, reflecting humanity’s tendency to overlook divine blessings both manifest and hidden. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that the greatest "favor" (ālā’) is the guidance of Wilayah—the divine guardianship embodied in the Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) and his purified progeny. Imam Ali (pbuh) states, *"The greatest blessing is recognition of the Imam, for it is the rope connecting creation to the Creator"* (Bihar al-Anwar). This verse thus challenges believers: Will you deny the ultimate gift of divine love and authority manifested in the Imams?  

Lady Fatimah (pbuh) illuminates this in her timeless sermon: *"Allah made obedience to us the foundation of His religion and our Wilayah the safeguard against division"* (Bihar al-Anwar). To deny any ālā’ is to reject the luminous chain of Imamah, the spiritual lifeline preserving Tawhid. Imam Sadiq (pbuh) explains that every blessing—from rain to revelation—flows through the channel of the Ahlul Bayt’s intercession (Tafsir al-Qummi). Thus, denying their station is akin to denying the sun’s light while basking in its warmth.  

Practically, this verse calls for constant gratitude (shukr) through adherence to the Imams’ teachings. Daily reflection on their sacrifices, reciting Ziyarat Ashura, and embodying their justice are acts of affirming divine favors. As Imam Ali (pbuh) taught, *"The heart of faith lies in acknowledging blessings and their Source."* To internalize this verse is to walk the path of wilayah, transforming every breath into a testimony of love for the Fourteen Infallibles, the ultimate manifestations of Allah’s mercy.

65.layer5:
The repeated verse “So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?” (Q55:65) serves as a rhetorical refrain in Surah Ar-Rahman, inviting reflection on divine blessings. Both Shia and Sunni exegetes broadly concur that the “favors” (ālā’) encompass Allah’s tangible and spiritual gifts, including creation, sustenance, and prophetic guidance. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) emphasize the verse’s universal address to humans and jinn, urging gratitude for shared blessings like celestial order and earthly resources. Ibn Kathir and Al-Tusi similarly stress the verse’s moral function: challenging denial of divine grace, whether through ingratitude or disbelief.  

Divergences emerge in contextualizing these “favors.” Shia commentaries, particularly Al-Qummi’s *Tafsir*, often link blessings to the theological concept of *walayah* (divinely ordained guardianship), interpreting the verse as an implicit reference to the Ahl al-Bayt’s leadership. Al-Mizan by Tabatabai frames the verse’s repetition as a gradual unveiling of truths, culminating in recognition of the Imams as manifestations of Allah’s mercy. In contrast, Sunni scholars like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi prioritize the verse’s immediate cosmological and ethical dimensions, highlighting blessings such as the Quran, prophethood, and natural phenomena without explicit connection to post-prophetic leadership.  

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Shia tafsir integrates the Imamate into its hermeneutics, viewing it as a continuation of prophetic guidance, while Sunni exegesis often centers on communal consensus and the Quran-Sunnah nexus. Practically, this influences devotional emphasis, with Shia tradition underscoring loyalty to the Imams as a divine favor, and Sunni discourse focusing on gratitude for prophetic teachings and communal unity. Historically, these interpretations reflect early theological developments, with Shia thought crystallizing around the status of the Ahl al-Bayt and Sunni scholarship prioritizing the preservation of prophetic precedent. Both traditions, however, unite in affirming the verse’s core message: human accountability before divine benevolence.

66.layer1:
In Surah Ar-Rahman, verse 66, Allah describes two gardens of Paradise with the phrase *فِيهِمَا عَيْنَانِ نَضَّاخَتَانِ* ("In both of them are two springs, spouting"). This verse, part of a larger passage detailing divine blessings for the righteous, uses vivid imagery to convey the abundance and perfection of Allah’s rewards. The dual gardens (*jannatān*) mentioned here are understood by Shia scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Tafsir al-Mizan* to symbolize distinct levels of spiritual proximity to Allah, reflecting the Quranic theme of layered rewards based on one’s deeds. The "two springs" (*‘aynān*) are described as *nadākhatān*, derived from the root *nadakha* (to gush or flow vigorously), emphasizing their ceaseless, life-giving nature—a metaphor for divine mercy and sustenance that never diminishes.

Historically, this Makkan surah aimed to awaken hearts to Allah’s universal signs and the Hereafter’s reality, countering Meccan polytheism. Shia tradition often interprets such descriptions of Paradise as both literal truths and allegories for spiritual realities. For instance, the "springs" can symbolize the eternal wisdom and guidance flowing through the Ahlul Bayt, as emphasized in narrations linking divine knowledge to the Imams’ role as spiritual guides. The verse’s structure—repeating "Which of your Lord’s blessings will you deny?"—invites reflection on gratitude (shukr), a key Islamic ethic.

Today, this verse reminds Muslims to seek balance: appreciating material blessings while nurturing spiritual growth through Quranic teachings and the Ahlul Bayt’s legacy. The "gushing springs" inspire trust in Allah’s boundless provision during hardship and a responsibility to channel His blessings—knowledge, resources, or faith—generously into the world, mirroring the ceaseless flow of divine grace.
66.layer2:
In Surah Ar-Rahman (55:66), the description of two gardens containing "two springs, spouting" (ʿaynāni naḍḍākhatāni) is interpreted by classical Shia exegetes as a profound metaphor for divine generosity and the metaphysical structure of Paradise. Both Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* and Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* emphasize that the "two springs" symbolize the inexhaustible abundance of Allah’s mercy, with Tabrisi noting their literal and allegorical dimensions: physically, they represent celestial blessings, while spiritually, they signify the eternal flow of divine grace to the righteous. The term *naḍḍākhatāni* (spouting) is derived from the root *naḍakha*, connoting vigorous, ceaseless emission, which Tabatabai links to the unending sustenance prepared for those who attain proximity to Allah through faith and devotion.

Shia commentators uniquely connect this imagery to the theological concept of *walayah* (divine guardianship), asserting that the "two springs" metaphorically reflect the twin sources of guidance: the Quran and the Ahl al-Bayt. This duality mirrors the Hadith al-Thaqalayn, where the Prophet Muhammad (s) declared the Quran and his purified progeny as inseparable guides. The springs’ perpetual flow thus represents the uninterrupted spiritual nourishment provided by the Imams, who are the "springs of wisdom" (ʿuyūn al-ḥikmah) in Shia cosmology. 

Jurisprudentially, the verse underscores the principle that divine rewards are contingent upon righteous action and adherence to the divinely appointed path. As emphasized in Shia doctrine, the ultimate realization of these celestial blessings is inseparable from recognition of the Imams’ ontological role as channels of Allah’s mercy. The duality in the verse—two gardens, two springs—further signifies the hierarchical nature of Paradise, reflecting varying degrees of spiritual attainment, a theme recurrent in Shia eschatology.
66.layer3:
In Surah Ar-Rahman (55:66), the imagery of “two springs, spouting” has inspired rich contemporary Shia scholarship that bridges metaphysical symbolism with urgent ecological and social concerns. Modern scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir-e Nemooneh*, contextualise these celestial springs as metaphors for divine abundance and balance—principles that resonate deeply with today’s environmental crises. The verse’s emphasis on water, a life-sustaining resource, is increasingly interpreted through the lens of climate justice, with scholars such as Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali linking it to Islam’s ethical mandate to protect natural systems. In a world where 2.2 billion lack safe drinking water (UNICEF 2023), the “spouting springs” symbolise both divine generosity and human responsibility to ensure equitable access.  

Scientifically, the verse’s description of pressurised, gushing water aligns with modern hydrology’s understanding of artesian wells—a connection noted by Iranian physicist Dr. Mehdi Golshani in interdisciplinary Quranic studies. Philosophically, contemporary thinkers like Dr. Liyakat Takim highlight the duality in the verse (“two springs”) as an invitation to harmonise material and spiritual progress, critiquing consumerist cultures that exploit resources without ethical restraint.  

Interfaith dialogues, particularly with Indigenous and Hindu traditions emphasising sacred rivers, amplify the verse’s call for cross-cultural environmental solidarity. The Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on stewardship (e.g., Imam Ali’s maxim “Do not waste water even if you are at a flowing spring”) gain new urgency amid droughts and privatisation disputes. Ultimately, this verse challenges modern societies to revere water as both a divine gift and a shared trust—a perspective vital for addressing scarcity, pollution, and intergenerational equity in our fractured world.
66.layer4:
In the luminous gardens of Paradise described in Surah Ar-Rahman, Allah (swt) paints a vision of two gushing springs (55:66), which the Ahlul Bayt (as) unveil as profound symbols of divine guidance. Imam Jafar as-Sadiq (as) taught that these springs represent the *'Ilm al-Batin* (hidden knowledge) and *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) flowing eternally from the Prophet (pbuh) and his purified progeny. He states: "The two springs are Ali and Fatimah—from them gush forth the rivers of knowledge and Imamate for the worlds" (*Bihar al-Anwar*). This metaphor reveals that the spiritual sustenance of humanity emerges from the union of Imam Ali's (as) divinely appointed authority and Lady Fatimah's (as) sanctified essence, the source of the Imams' lineage.  

The "spouting" (naddakhatan) nature of these springs signifies the ceaseless, dynamic outpouring of wisdom through the Imams' teachings. Just as water revives barren land, the Ahlul Bayt's (as) guidance nourishes souls trapped in the drought of ignorance. The 6th Imam (as) explained: "Our Wilayah is the spring that never dries; whoever turns to it in thirst will never thirst again" (*Tafsir al-Qummi*). Practically, this verse invites believers to drink deeply from the fountain of the Imams' preserved teachings—through studying their hadith, embodying their ethics, and seeking intercession via their sacred names.  

To access these spiritual springs, one must cultivate the "eye of the heart" by aligning one's will with the Imams' divine mandate. As Imam Ali (as) advised: "Purify your vessel before filling it"—meaning cleanse the soul through repentance and devotion to rightly receive this flowing wisdom. The two gardens thus mirror the twin luminous paths of knowledge (*'ilm*) and loving obedience (*tahabbub*) to Muhammad (pbuh) and his Household, the only channels to eternal flourishing.

66.layer5:
In Surah Ar-Rahman 55:66, the description of two gushing springs in Paradise has drawn convergent literal interpretations across Shia and Sunni traditions, while differing in symbolic dimensions. Both schools agree on the verse’s primary meaning as depicting Paradise’s physical and spiritual bounties, with scholars like Tabari (Sunni) and Tabrisi (Shia) emphasizing the term *naddakhatan* (spouting) as indicative of abundant, ceaseless flow, reflecting divine generosity. Ibn Kathir and Tusi both contextualize this within the Quran’s broader motif of Paradise’s perfection, aligning with the verse’s rhetorical structure in Surah Ar-Rahman.  

Key differences emerge in hermeneutical approaches. Shia exegetes like Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) and Qummi often extend the imagery to metaphysical realities, interpreting the “two springs” as symbols of divinely guided knowledge flowing through the Ahlul Bayt. This aligns with Shia theological emphasis on the Imams’ role as spiritual conduits. In contrast, Sunni scholars such as Qurtubi and Razi focus on the springs’ literal description, linking them to sensory delights for the righteous without explicit allegorical readings. Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) acknowledges symbolic potential but cautions against overinterpretation absent clear textual evidence.  

These divergences stem from distinct epistemological frameworks: Shia tafsir frequently integrates hadiths from the Imams as interpretive authorities, while Sunni exegesis prioritizes prophetic traditions and companion narrations. Practically, Shia interpretations may reinforce devotion to the Ahlul Bayt as sources of spiritual nourishment, whereas Sunni readings emphasize gratitude for divine blessings. Historically, such differences reflect broader theological developments post-7th century, particularly Shia efforts to root authority in the Prophet’s household versus Sunni consolidation around textual and communal consensus. Both traditions, however, unite in viewing the verse as an affirmation of Allah’s mercy and the believer’s ultimate reward.

67.layer1:
In Surah Ar-Rahman, verse 67, Allah repeats the profound refrain *"Fabiyyi ala'i rabbikuma tukadhiban"* ("So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?"), a question echoed 31 times in the chapter. This verse follows descriptions of divine blessings, from the creation of humans and jinn to the marvels of nature, urging reflection on Allah’s endless mercy. The dual address *"rabbikuma"* ("your Lord") speaks to both humanity and jinn, emphasizing that all beings are bound to the same Creator. The term *"ala'"* (favors) refers not only to tangible gifts like water, fertile land, and sustenance but also to spiritual blessings such as guidance through prophets and the Ahlul Bayt, whom Shia tradition regards as Allah’s enduring mercy to humanity.  

Historical tafsirs, including Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, note that this Meccan surah confronted the arrogance of disbelievers who dismissed Allah’s signs despite living amid His generosity. The rhetorical question challenges denial (*tukadhiban*) of truth, linking ingratitude (*kufr al-ni'mah*) to spiritual blindness. For Shia Muslims, this verse underscores the necessity of recognizing Imam Ali and the Imams as divine gifts, inseparable from the Quran’s guidance.  

Today, this verse calls Muslims to audit their gratitude. In an age of materialism and distraction, it asks: Do we deny Allah’s favors by neglecting prayer, ignoring social justice, or dismissing the moral framework of the Ahlul Bayt? Modern "denials" might include exploiting natural resources without stewardship, overlooking the poor, or prioritizing ego over humility. By internalizing *"fabiyyi ala'i rabbikuma tukadhiban"*, believers renew their commitment to gratitude (*shukr*)—through worship, ethical living, and upholding the teachings of the Prophet’s Household, ensuring divine blessings resonate in both action and heart.
67.layer2:
In Surah Ar-Rahman (55:67), the divine refrain *"So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?"* recurs as a profound rhetorical device, compelling humanity to reflect on Allah’s innumerable blessings. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, emphasize that this verse—like its repetitions throughout the surah—serves as both a reminder and a rebuke. The "favors" (*ala'*) encompass both tangible creations (e.g., celestial order, earthly sustenance) and spiritual gifts, particularly the guidance of divine revelation and the *wilayah* (guardianship) of the Ahl al-Bayt. Tabrisi notes that the dual address (*"your Lord"*, referring to both jinn and humans) underscores universal accountability, demanding recognition of blessings as manifestations of divine mercy (*rahmah*) and justice (*adl*).

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in Shia traditions, interprets the denial of favors as encompassing rejection of prophetic missions and the Imamate, since spiritual guidance constitutes the ultimate divine bounty. This aligns with the Shia theological principle that recognizing the *Muhammadan light* and the infallible Imams is inseparable from gratitude (*shukr*) to Allah. Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, expands this by framing the verse within the surah’s cosmic narrative: after enumerating physical marvels (e.g., dual heavens, lush gardens), the rhetorical question elevates the discourse to metaphysical realities, where rejecting truth becomes a moral and existential contradiction. 

The verse thus bridges creation and creed, urging acknowledgment of both material and spiritual blessings. In Shia jurisprudence, this fosters an ethical framework where gratitude entails not only ritual worship but also adherence to the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt, who embody divine wisdom. Denial (*takdhib*), in this context, becomes synonymous with ingratitude (*kufr al-ni'mah*), a theological failing with eschatological consequences. The refrain’s repetition, as classical commentators stress, mirrors the persistent human tendency to neglect divine signs, necessitating constant reminder and self-reckoning.
67.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Rahman’s recurring verse *“So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?”* (55:67) is interpreted as a profound call to recognize divine blessings (ni’mah) in both cosmic and quotidian dimensions. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi emphasizes that this rhetorical question challenges humanity’s tendency to overlook Allah’s Rahmaniyyah (all-encompassing mercy) embedded in ecological balance, human consciousness, and societal harmony. Modern exegetes like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali link this verse to environmental stewardship, arguing that climate change and biodiversity loss exemplify humanity’s “denial” of divine gifts by disrupting Earth’s equilibrium—a theme echoed in Imam Ali’s Nahj al-Balagha, which urges responsible custodianship of nature.  

Philosophically, scholars such as Sayyed Kamal al-Haydari connect the verse to existential gratitude, framing technological progress and medical advancements not as purely human achievements but as manifestations of divine grace requiring ethical application. Socially, the verse critiques consumerist cultures that normalize excess while billions face poverty—a disparity Shia NGOs like Imam Khomeini Relief Foundation address through Quranic principles of equitable resource distribution.  

Interfaith dialogues, particularly with Christian and Jewish environmentalists, highlight shared Abrahamic values on creation care, positioning this verse as a universal appeal against ecological apathy. In multicultural contexts, the refrain’s poetic repetition resonates as a meditative tool for mindfulness, urging believers and skeptics alike to “count blessings” in an age of existential anxiety. Ultimately, this verse bridges tawhid (divine unity) with modern challenges, transforming passive thankfulness into active justice-seeking—a dynamic spirituality for today’s fractured world.
67.layer4:
In the luminous verses of Surah Ar-Rahman, Allah repeatedly questions humanity and jinn: *"So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?"* (55:67). The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that this divine refrain is not merely about material blessings but a profound call to recognize the ultimate spiritual gifts: the light of guidance through **Wilayah** (divine guardianship) and the eternal covenant of **Imamah** (divinely appointed leadership).  

Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states, *"The greatest of Allah’s favors is the recognition of His Proof [the Imam] in every age. Whoever denies this has denied all favors"* (Bihar al-Anwar). This ties the verse’s meaning to the necessity of acknowledging the Imams as manifestations of Allah’s mercy. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasized that true gratitude lies in aligning one’s actions with divine truth, declaring, *"The gratitude of the tongue is praise, but the gratitude of the soul is sincerity in deeds"* (Bihar al-Anwar).  

The "favors" mentioned thus encompass both tangible blessings and the unseen grace of the Ahlul Bayt’s intercession, teachings, and purified lineage. To deny their status as the Ark of Salvation—a metaphor Imam Ali (peace be upon him) used—is to reject the very means by which Allah’s mercy flows to creation.  

Practically, this verse invites believers to deepen their connection to the Imams through daily reflection on their rights (Haqq) over us, as taught by Imam Zain al-Abidin (peace be upon him) in the *Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya*. Spiritual development here means embodying gratitude by upholding justice, seeking nearness to the Imams in prayer, and resisting the *nafs* (ego) that blinds one to their light. Each act of loyalty to their teachings becomes a affirmation of Allah’s endless favors.

بین المذاہب مکالمے ، خاص طور پر عیسائی اور یہودی ماحولیات کے ماہرین کے ساتھ ، تخلیق کی دیکھ بھال پر مشترکہ ابراہیمک اقدار کو اجاگر کرتے ہیں ، اور اس آیت کو ماحولیاتی بے حسی کے خلاف عالمی اپیل کے طور پر رکھتے ہیں۔ کثیر الثقافتی سیاق و سباق میں ، پرہیزگار کی شاعرانہ تکرار ذہن سازی کے لئے ایک مراقبہ کے آلے کے طور پر گونجتی ہے ، اور مومنین اور شکیوں کو یکساں طور پر بے چینی کے دور میں "نعمتوں کی گنتی" کرنے کی تاکید کرتی ہے۔ آخر کار ، یہ آیت توہڈ (الہی اتحاد) کو جدید چیلنجوں کے ساتھ پل کرتی ہے ، جس سے غیر فعال شکرگزار کو فعال انصاف کی تلاش میں تبدیل کیا جاتا ہے۔

67.layer5:
The refrain *“So which of the favors of your Lord would you deny?”* (Qur’an 55:67) appears repeatedly in Surah Ar-Rahman, inviting reflection on divine blessings. Both Shia and Sunni exegetes emphasize the verse’s rhetorical force as a call to acknowledge Allah’s innumerable mercies. Tabatabai (Shia, *Al-Mizan*) and Ibn Kathir (Sunni) concur that the verse underscores humanity’s moral obligation to recognize divine grace, with Qurtubi (*Al-Jami*) adding that its repetition amplifies the urgency of gratitude. Across traditions, scholars agree the verse addresses both humans and jinn, as indicated by the dual pronoun *“kumā”* (your two kinds), reflecting a shared cosmic theology of creation’s purpose.  

Interpretive divergences emerge in defining the scope of “favors” (*ālā’*). Shia commentators often extend its meaning to include spiritual and ontological gifts, particularly the guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt. Tabrisi (*Majma al-Bayan*) and Tusi (*At-Tibyan*) frame the Imams’ leadership as a foundational divine favor, inseparable from Qur’anic revelation—a perspective rooted in the Shia theological axiom of *wilāyah* (divinely ordained authority). In contrast, Sunni exegetes like Tabari (*Jami al-Bayan*) and Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) prioritize tangible blessings enumerated in the surah (e.g., celestial order, natural resources) and the universality of Muhammad’s prophethood, aligning with Sunni emphasis on communal consensus (*ijmāʿ*) and accessible ethical reflection.  

These distinctions subtly influence religious practice: Shia spirituality may emphasize devotion to the Imams as embodiments of divine grace, while Sunni traditions often channel gratitude into broader acts of worship and social ethics. Historically, Shia interpretations arose from early theological debates over leadership and esoteric knowledge, whereas Sunni exegesis developed within frameworks prioritizing textual literalism and communal unity. Both traditions, however, unite in viewing the verse as a timeless reminder to cultivate conscious thankfulness (*shukr*), demonstrating how shared Qur’anic principles adapt to distinct theological paradigms without contradiction.

68.layer1:
In Surah Ar-Rahman (55:68), Allah describes two gardens of Paradise (jannatān) with the words *"Feehima fakihatun wa nakhlun wa rumman"*—"In both of them are fruit, palm trees, and pomegranates." This verse is part of a larger passage (55:46–76) detailing the blessings awaiting the righteous, emphasizing Allah’s boundless mercy (rahmah) and the tangible rewards of faith. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that these gardens symbolise both the spiritual and physical abundance granted to those who uphold divine guidance, reflecting the Quran’s layered approach to describing the unseen.  

The mention of *fakihatun* (fruit), *nakhlun* (date palms), and *rummanun* (pomegranates) carries symbolic weight. Date palms and pomegranates are not only earthly blessings but also hold sacred resonance in Islamic tradition. For instance, dates are linked to sustenance and prophetic teachings (e.g., Prophet Muhammad’s emphasis on breaking fasts with them), while pomegranates are mentioned in narrations from Imam Ali as symbols of divine wisdom and the interconnectedness of creation. Historically, this Meccan surah aimed to awaken hearts to Allah’s generosity amid early Muslim persecution, offering hope and affirming that devotion yields eternal prosperity.  

Today, this verse invites Muslims to recognise blessings in both material and spiritual forms. The "two gardens" can be interpreted as reminders to balance worldly gratitude with investment in the hereafter—cherishing nature’s gifts while upholding justice, charity, and adherence to the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings. The pairing of tangible fruits (like dates) and symbolic ones (like pomegranates’ nourishing seeds) mirrors the Shia ethos of harmonising outward worship with inner reflection. By valuing Allah’s provisions and striving for spiritual growth, believers cultivate their own "gardens" of faith, preparing for the ultimate reward promised in this radiant surah.
68.layer2:
In Surah Ar-Rahman (55:68), the mention of dual gardens containing "fruit, palm trees, and pomegranates" has been interpreted by classical Shia scholars through both literal and allegorical lenses, reflecting the tradition’s integration of zahir (apparent) and batin (esoteric) exegesis. Al-Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, emphasizes the verse’s alignment with the Qur’anic motif of duality—here symbolizing the complementary blessings of the material and spiritual realms. The "two gardens" are understood as earthly paradisiacal prototypes and their perfected counterparts in the hereafter, a theme recurrent in Shia cosmology that underscores the continuity between creation and divine purpose.

Al-Tabrisi and Al-Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) both highlight the symbolic resonance of the enumerated fruits. Dates (nakhl) and pomegranates (rumman) are traditionally associated with prophetic and Alid narratives; dates evoke the Prophet Muhammad’s fondness for them and their role in sustaining the Ahlul Bayt, while pomegranates are linked to Imam Ali’s descriptions of divine wisdom’s multiplicity. The inclusion of "fruit" (fakiha) in a general sense signifies the comprehensiveness of divine provision, inviting reflection on both physical sustenance and spiritual nourishment.

Theologically, Shia commentators connect this verse to the concept of *tawhid al-af’al* (unity of divine acts), wherein all blessings—whether tangible or metaphysical—emanate from Allah’s mercy (Rahmaniyya). The duality of gardens also subtly alludes to the Shia doctrine of *walayah*, where the material world’s blessings are perfected through the guidance of the Imams, who serve as conduits for divine grace. Jurisprudentially, the verse reinforces the obligation of gratitude (shukr) for divine favors, a principle foundational to Shia ethics and ritual practice. As Al-Tabatabai notes, the pairing of gardens reflects the Qur’anic balance between human responsibility as *khalifa* (vicegerent) and Allah’s boundless generosity—a duality resolved through adherence to the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt.
68.layer3:
In Surah Rahman (55:68), the mention of fruits, palm trees, and pomegranates in the paradisiacal gardens has inspired contemporary Shia scholars to reflect on both the spiritual and ecological dimensions of divine bounty. Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi, in his exegesis *Payam-e Quran*, emphasizes that these symbols of abundance are not merely otherworldly metaphors but reminders of humanity’s responsibility to steward Earth’s resources wisely. The verse’s pairing of “two gardens” (referenced earlier in the surah) is interpreted as an invitation to balance material prosperity with spiritual growth, echoing the Quranic principle of *mizan* (divine equilibrium).  

Modern scientific insights add depth to this reading. Pomegranates, rich in antioxidants, and date palms, resilient in arid climates, exemplify nature’s adaptability—a theme resonating with today’s climate crisis. Scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to the Islamic ethic of environmental custodianship, urging Muslims to address deforestation and water scarcity as acts of faith. Socially, the verse critiques global inequities: while some nations overconsume, others face food insecurity, violating the Quranic call for equitable distribution (*qist*).  

Philosophically, the pomegranate’s unity-in-diversity—many seeds within one fruit—mirrors the Shia emphasis on *tawhid* (divine unity) amid human plurality. Interfaith dialogues, particularly with Jewish and Christian traditions that also revere pomegranates as symbols of righteousness, highlight shared values of gratitude and sustainability.  

In essence, this verse bridges the transcendent and the tangible, urging believers to see ecological and social justice as inseparable from spiritual duty—a vision deeply aligned with the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on compassion and cosmic harmony.
68.layer4:
The gardens described in Surah Ar-Rahman (55:68) are illuminated by the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) as manifestations of divine wisdom and spiritual realities. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) taught that "every fruit in Paradise is a symbol of the knowledge Allah grants to the hearts of the believers through the light of wilayah (divine guardianship)." The palm tree, revered in hadith as "the tree from which Allah fashioned Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his progeny)," represents the towering spiritual stature of the Prophet and his purified progeny. The pomegranate, with its countless seeds united under one rind, symbolises the unity of divine truths guarded by the Imams – as Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) said: "We are the encompassing ark of Allah's unity."

Practical wisdom emerges when we reflect on Imam Ali's (peace be upon him) teaching: "The fruits of Paradise grow from the seeds of earthly obedience." Each act of love for the Ahlul Bayt, each adherence to their teachings, nourishes these celestial trees within our souls. The "two gardens" are interpreted by scholars as the twin realms of outer devotion (sharia) and inner realization (haqiqa), cultivated through loyalty to the Imams. To taste these fruits, one must emulate Imam Zayn al-Abidin's (peace be upon him) counsel in Sahifa Sajjadiyya: "Make our love the irrigating rain for the garden of our hearts." 

True palm trees of faith grow when we anchor ourselves in the Prophet's household, as the Quranic date palm is deeply rooted yet reaches heavenward. The pomegranate's ruby seeds remind us that every divine truth – from prayer to pilgrimage – finds its radiant purpose through the Imamah. As we partake of earthly fruits, let them be reminders to nourish our souls with the eternal fruits of the Prophet's progeny.

سورہ آر الرحمن (55:68) میں ، اللہ تعالی نے جنت کے دو باغات (جنناٹان) کو الفاظ کے ساتھ بیان کیا ہے *"فیہیما فاکیہٹن وا نخلون و رومن" *-"ان دونوں میں پھل ، کھجور کے درخت اور انار ہیں۔" یہ آیت ایک بڑے حصے (55: 46–76) کا ایک حصہ ہے جس میں نیک لوگوں کے منتظر نعمتوں کی تفصیل ہے ، جس میں اللہ کی بے حد رحمت (رحمہ) اور عقیدے کے ٹھوس انعامات پر زور دیا گیا ہے۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ طافس ، جیسے الامہ تبتابائی کے *المزان *، نے وضاحت کی ہے کہ یہ باغات ان لوگوں کو دیئے گئے روحانی اور جسمانی کثرت دونوں کی علامت ہیں جو الہی رہنمائی کو برقرار رکھتے ہیں ، جو غصے کو بیان کرنے کے لئے قرآن کی پرتوں کے نقطہ نظر کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں۔

آج ، یہ آیت مسلمانوں کو مادی اور روحانی دونوں شکلوں میں نعمتوں کو تسلیم کرنے کی دعوت دیتی ہے۔ "دو باغات" کو اس کے بعد میں سرمایہ کاری کے ساتھ دنیاوی شکرگزار کو متوازن کرنے کے لئے یاد دہانیوں کے طور پر سمجھا جاسکتا ہے۔ ٹھوس پھلوں کی جوڑی (جیسے تاریخیں) اور علامتی اشاروں (جیسے انار ’پرورش کرنے والے بیج) اندرونی عکاسی کے ساتھ ظاہری عبادت کو ہم آہنگ کرنے کے شیعہ اخلاق کو آئینہ دار بناتے ہیں۔ اللہ کی دفعات کی قدر کرکے اور روحانی نشوونما کے لئے جدوجہد کرکے ، مومنین اپنے "باغات" عقیدے کے اپنے "باغات" کاشت کرتے ہیں ، اور اس تابوت سورہ میں وعدہ کردہ حتمی انعام کی تیاری کرتے ہیں۔

الاتبریسی اور الاتعباتابائی (*العزان*) دونوں گنتی پھلوں کی علامتی گونج کو اجاگر کرتے ہیں۔ تاریخیں (NAKHL) اور انار (رم مین) روایتی طور پر پیشن گوئی اور مضمر بیانیہ سے وابستہ ہیں۔ تاریخوں نے ان کے لئے حضرت محمد صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم اور اہل بیت کو برقرار رکھنے میں ان کے کردار کو جنم دیا ہے ، جبکہ انار کو امام علی کی الہی حکمت کی ضرب کی وضاحت سے منسلک کیا جاتا ہے۔ عام معنوں میں "پھل" (فاکیہ) کی شمولیت الہی فراہمی کی جامعیت کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے ، اور جسمانی رزق اور روحانی پرورش دونوں پر عکاسی کی دعوت دیتا ہے۔

مذہبی طور پر ، شیعہ مبصرین اس آیت کو * توحید الافال * (الہی عمل کا اتحاد) کے تصور سے مربوط کرتے ہیں ، جس میں تمام نعمتیں-چاہے ٹھوس ہوں یا استعاریاتی-اللہ کی رحمت (رحمانیہ) سے منسلک ہوں۔ باغات کی دوئم *والیہ *کے شیعہ نظریے کی بھی پوری طرح سے اشارہ کرتی ہے ، جہاں مادی دنیا کی نعمتوں کو اماموں کی رہنمائی کے ذریعے کمال کیا جاتا ہے ، جو خدائی فضل کے لئے نزاکت کے طور پر کام کرتے ہیں۔ فقہی طور پر ، آیت الہی کے حامیوں کے لئے شکرگزار (SUKR) کی ذمہ داری کو تقویت دیتی ہے ، جو شیعہ اخلاقیات اور رسمی عمل کے لئے ایک بنیادی اصول ہے۔ جیسا کہ التبطابائی نوٹ کرتا ہے ، باغات کی جوڑی انسانی ذمہ داری کے مابین قرآنی توازن کی عکاسی کرتی ہے جیسے * خلیفہ * (وائسجرینٹ) اور اللہ کی بے حد سخاوت-ایک دوہری اسلول بیت کی تعلیمات پر عمل پیرا ہونے کے ذریعے حل کی گئی ہے۔

In interpreting Surah Ar-Rahman 55:68, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core themes while exhibiting distinct hermeneutical emphases. Classical commentators across traditions, including Tabari (Sunni) and Tabrisi (Shia), agree the verse describes paradisiacal gardens containing abundant blessings, with fruits symbolising divine generosity. Ibn Kathir and Qummi both emphasise the literal reality of these gardens as rewards for the righteous, reflecting shared eschatological principles. The pomegranate’s mention is universally acknowledged as denoting both sensory delight and spiritual symbolism, with Qurtubi and Tusi noting its Qur’anic recurrence as a sign of God’s creative majesty.  

Divergences emerge in theological subtexts. Sunni scholars like Razi prioritise the verse’s ethical implications, framing the fruits as metaphors for cultivated virtues. In *Mafatih al-Ghayb*, Razi links palm trees to steadfastness in faith, reflecting Sunni emphasis on individual moral responsibility. Shia sources, particularly Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, extend the symbolism to ontological realities, interpreting the “two gardens” as allegories for complementary spiritual realms accessible through devotion to the Ahl al-Bayt. Al-Qummi’s tafsir subtly associates the pomegranate’s layered seeds with the hidden knowledge of the Imams, a perspective rooted in Shia cosmology’s emphasis on divinely guided hermeneutics.  

These differences stem from distinct epistemological frameworks: Sunni exegesis often prioritises transmitted traditions (naql) and apparent meanings (zahir), while Shia scholarship integrates intellectual reasoning (‘aql) with esoteric interpretations (batin) tied to Imamology. Practically, this shapes devotional focus—Sunni applications stress gratitude for tangible blessings, whereas Shia spirituality may emphasise seeking transcendent truths through the Imams’ guidance. Historically, such variations reflect early theological developments, with Shia tafsir evolving alongside doctrinal articulations of walaya, while Sunni approaches solidified through hadith-centric methodologies. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s core message: God’s boundless mercy manifested in creation’s marvels.
